bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 12, 1900

div1.p: Lawrence Reed writes that he is not certain where he will be sent next. He asks her to remind Walter Reed about his sword.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 12, 1900
div1.p:
I have an hour and
a half before breakfast and as I was
unable to write you yesterday as I
promised I would, I will do so
this morning.

Well, this is more like
it, I am beginning to feel the freedom
of life and am beginning to enjoy it
once more, and let me state right
here that it is well worth the 2 years
I spent as an enlisted man, of course
if I should have to go over it again I would
but now that I have ended those
days I feel as though Uncle
Sam is very good to allow a
man such a reward for such short
service.

As yet I dont know when
I will leave for my new station
or where that is, but it seems to
be the general impression that I
will not have a chance to visit
you this time, it makes it very
inconvenien too, for there are a lot of things
I should like, and dont care to purchase
them here. Please remind father of my sword
as it is the most important of all, the
rest of the things are less important and most
of them can wait, I have got to get my
a blue uniform, but will not do any thing
about it until later on in the year. Today
is mail day and it may bring me good news.

This makes my second tour of officer of the day
so I am getting good practice already. I am
attached to “N” Batty for duty and am Post Adjutant.
Capt Harmon is just as kind to me as he can be and I
should like to be under him.

Well dearest I will let you know any
change I make just as soon as possible. Do
write to me soon. Tell Mable I will answer
her letter real soon, and with lots of love
for you all I am.
div1.closer:
Your aff son Lawrence. P.S. Father might arrange for me to be allowed a delay so
that I could step up to see you, but by the time I get this
I suppose I will have my orders, L.
